recommendations.recommendation: great characters, wacky animation, funny realization, sora <3
The best, and most overlooked, anime in a couple of years. With only 2 exceptions, enjoyed the whole thing, through to the very end. No series ruining ending here.

Nakashima Kazuki`s (Gurren Lagann) screenplay shines not only because of the animation, style and directing which are all well amongst the best in the recent years. The witty humour and depiction of old Edo as well as the whimsical characters do also their part to make this show fun to enjoy.

anime.description: Early in summer, the 13th year of Tempo, due to the Tempo Reforms proclaimed by Mizuno Tadakuni, people in Edo are prohibited from living extravagantly and luxuriously. http://anidb.net/ch12642 [Tamaya Seikichi], a craftsman of fireworks, cannot abandon his dream to create new and larger fireworks than anyone has ever seen. Every day, he secretly launches fireworks and evades the authorities. One night, two beasts are cornered by government officers. The blue one is killed, but the white one escapes into the darkness. Part of the reason they miss the white one is Seikichi`s fireworks. The next morning, http://anidb.net/ch12643 [Sora], a mysterious and beautiful girl, appears and asks Seikichi to make a firework that can reach the moon. Although he is embarrassed by her request, he begins to make fireworks in order to encourage people depressed by the reforms. In the row house he lives in, various kinds of people, such as a carpenter, an entertainer, a magician, a mechanic, etc. reside there. With the help of those people and http://anidb.net/ch12644 [Shunpei], Seikichi`s little brother, who is also a good mathematician, their Moon Rocket Plan begins to take shape. Will he be able to shoot a rocket to the moon? Source: AnimeNfo

tag.name: alien
tag.description: This entity or creature was born on another world than the main characters.

tag.name: content indicators
tag.description: The content indicators branch is intended to be a less geographically specific tool than the `age rating` used by convention, for warning about things that might cause offence. Obviously there is still a degree of subjectivity involved, but hopefully it will prove useful for parents with delicate children, or children with delicate parents. Note: Refer to further guidance on http://wiki.anidb.net/w/Categories:Content_Indicators [the Wiki page] for how to apply tag weights for content indicators.

tag.name: dynamic
tag.description: Some of the central structural elements in anime are: Plot Continuity How does the plot or several plots unfold. Are they a strictly linear retelling of one big continuing story, a serial, possibly with several side stories, or is the content chopped into a set of unconnected episodes, only sharing the same setting and characters? Stereotype Characters Then there is the question of the character set presentation. Is it completely original, or is it your usual stereotypical character cast. Both choices have their merit, for example it would not really make much sense to reinvent the wheel for a harem anime. Fans of that genre come to expect their favourite stereotype protagonists. Plot Twists Finally there is the question of how complex the plot / the story unfolds. Are there side-plots that merge into the main plot leading to unexpected plot twists, or is the anime quite predictable? The latter would not be appropriate for detective stories. In harem anime on the other hand a foreseeable outcome is actually something the fans will come to expect.

tag.name: themes
tag.description: Themes describe the very central elements important to the anime stories. They set the backdrop against which the protagonists must face their challenges. Be it School Life, present Daily Life, Military action, Cyberpunk, Law and Order detective work, Sports, or the Underworld. These are only but a few of the more typical backgrounds for anime plots. Add to that a Conspiracy setting with a possible tragic outcome, the Themes span most of the imaginable subject matter relevant to anime.

tag.name: original work
tag.description: What the anime is based on! This is given as the original work credit in the OP. Mostly of academic interest, but a useful bit of info, hinting at the possible depth of story.

tag.name: setting
tag.description: The setting describes in what time and place an anime takes place. To a certain extent it describes what you can expect from the world in the anime.

tag.name: elements
tag.description: Next to Themes setting the backdrop for the protagonists in anime, there are the more detailed plot Elements that centre on character interactions: "What do characters do to each other or what is done to them?". Is it violent Action, an awe-inspiring Adventure in a foreign place, the gripping life of a Detective, a slapstick Comedy, an Ecchi Harem anime, a SciFi epic, or some Fantasy travelling adventure?

tag.name: time
tag.description: This placeholder lists different epochs in human history and more vague but important timelines such as the future, the present and the past.

tag.name: place
tag.description: The places the anime can take place in. Includes more specific places such as a country on Earth, as well as more general places such as a dystopia or a mirror world.

tag.name: swordplay
tag.description: The act or art of using a sword or similar weapon skillfully.

tag.name: past
tag.description: Anime that takes place in the past or clearly seems to take place in the past in case of an alternative universe. This category should almost always go together with one of its sub-categories, because the past can either be a depiction of a historical event(s) or not, in which case it would be alternative past.

tag.name: space
tag.description: The final frontier.

tag.name: Earth
tag.description: The Earth is the third planet from the Sun, and the densest and fifth-largest of the eight planets in the Solar System. It is in effect a ball of hot mud, but on the surface it`s cold enough, so most of us live on it (or are supposed to). It is circa 4.5 billion years old, and, unless we humans succeed in destroying it over the next couple of centuries, it is expected to last for quite another while, though the changes in the Sun`s emissions due to its aging will likely cause the extinction of everything; the species of earthlings are guaranteed to die, even if we fail to kill them -- unless, of course, we find ourselves another planet and figure out a way to take everything there. Our little planet on a corner of this galaxy may mean nothing in the grand scheme of things, but to its inhabitants it is their home, so, as a species, we cherish it dearly, to the point many cultures even to this day deify it. Being the home to the human civilizations, the Earth is the main setting of most fiction, be it anime or otherwise, but not only are many titles set in other places, such as unrelated fantasy worlds, in a considerable number of fictional titles the Earth is actually destroyed by aggressive alien invaders.

tag.name: space travel
tag.description: Space Travel usually refers going to space or travelling there with or without a spacecraft. There are different forms of space travel like Interplanetary travel, Interstellar travel or Intergalactic travel. Since it isn`t possible to travel faster than light, most anime series involve some sort "sub-space travel mechanism" as a way to travel faster than light.

tag.name: alternative past
tag.description: An anime that takes place in an alternative past is an anime that clearly does not belong to the future or the present, and isn`t tied particularly closely to our history, or has ties to our history but only as a premise: there are too many things that don`t make sense for the time-period. In some cases there is futuristic technology present, but the overall setting still feels that of the past. However the setting must still take place on Earth, since we can not know if the history of a fantasy world is an alternate one or not.

tag.name: slapstick
tag.description: Slapstick humour is generally recognized by lots of physical abuse, horseplay and practical jokes. Also often seen are impossible situations, using sounds to illustrate impossible stunts that aren`t shown on-screen and to create tension for audience anticipation.

tag.name: medium awareness
tag.description: Medium awareness is the situational and generally temporary awareness characters in works of fiction have and display of the very fact that they are characters in works of fiction. For example, they may comment about the background music, quip about the script or narration, complain about the roles given to them by the writer or their lack of screen time, see the subtitles that appear on screen, inform the audience about the arrival of the commercial break, and even use medium effects as tools. The most common form of medium awareness is known as breaking the fourth wall, in which characters speak directly to the audience, either to it as a whole or to specific members of it. The "fourth wall" is the imaginary "wall" at the front of the stage of a proscenium theatre through which the audience sees the play; it is a metaphor for the boundary between what happens inside the work, to the characters, and outside it, to the audience.

tag.name: parody
tag.description: Anime that imitate other stories (can be from TV, film, books, historical events, ...) for comic effect by exaggerating the style and changing the content of the original. Also known as spoofs. It can also refer to when whole elements of one work are lifted out of their context and reused.

tag.name: Moon
tag.description: The Moon is an astronomical body that orbits planet Earth, being Earth`s only permanent natural satellite. It is the fifth-largest natural satellite in the Solar System, and the largest among planetary satellites relative to the size of the planet that it orbits. Source: Wikipedia

tag.name: other planet
tag.description: The anime will fit this category if some or all of the action takes place on another planet which is supposedly in the same universe as Earth, not a complete fantasy world; usually there has to be some concept of space travel. The Latin name for Earth - Terra, would also pass the condition of being in the same universe as Earth. Basically, even mentioning of Earth existing or having existed would be enough. Although Moon is a moon, it also qualifies as Other Planet.

tag.name: Japan
tag.description: Japan is a sovereign island nation in East Asia. Located in the Pacific Ocean, it lies off the eastern coast of the Asian mainland and stretches from the Sea of Okhotsk in the north to the East China Sea and China in the southwest. Source: Wikipedia

tag.name: violence
tag.description: Violence is the use of physical force against oneself or another entity, compelling action against one`s will on pain of being hurt. Note: Refer to further guidance on http://wiki.anidb.net/w/Categories:Content_Indicators [the Wiki page] for how to apply tag weights for content indicators.

tag.name: love polygon
tag.description: A love polygon refers to a romantic relationship involving n people. Although a love triangle is not limited to just heterosexual relationships, in anime, it usually deals with two females liking one male and vice versa.

tag.name: plot continuity
tag.description: Consistency of the characteristics of persons, plot, objects, places and events seen by the viewer. A single linear focused plot is highly continuous. A truly random plot is highly discontinuous.

tag.name: new
tag.description: Not based on anything, the story is a new work, usually made up by the people involved in creating the anime. Generally if an original work (原作) credit is given, it will be to the studio, or director, or other members of the production team.

tag.name: Asia
tag.description: Asia is Earth`s largest and most populous continent, located primarily in the eastern and northern hemispheres and sharing the continental landmass of Eurasia with the continent of Europe. Asia covers an area of 44,579,000 square kilometers, about 30% of Earth`s total land area and 8.7% of the Earth`s total surface area. The continent, which has long been home to the majority of the human population, was the site of many of the first civilizations. Asia is notable for not only its overall large size and population, but also dense and large settlements as well as vast barely populated regions within the continent of 4.4 billion people. Source: Wikipedia

tag.name: action
tag.description: Action anime usually involve a fairly straightforward story of good guys versus bad guys, where most disputes are resolved by using physical force. It often contains a lot of shooting, explosions and fighting.

tag.name: science fiction
tag.description: Science fiction stories usually focus on how situations could be different in the future when we are more technologically advanced; due to either our own achievements or having met with other civilizations whom we have learned from.

tag.name: comedy
tag.description: Anime whose central struggle causes hilarious results. These stories are built upon funny characters, situations and events. A comedy anime is laced with humour and sets out to provoke laughter from the audience. Japanese humour can be a bit strange to westerners, so if you`re new to this type of humour, just bear with it; it`ll most likely grow on you if you`re a fan of other kinds of comedy.

tag.name: romance
tag.description: Romance describes a story that deals with love between two or more characters typically also having an optimistic ending. Romance is also a difficulty encountered when creating a harem.

tag.name: conspiracy
tag.description: The conspiracy thriller (or paranoid thriller) is a sub-genre of the thriller which flourished in the 1970s in the US (and was echoed in other parts of the world) in the wake of a number of high-profile scandals and controversies (most notably Vietnam, the assassination of President Kennedy, Chappaquiddick and Watergate), and which exposed what many people regarded as the clandestine machinations and conspiracies beneath the orderly fabric of political life. The protagonists of conspiracy thrillers are often journalists or amateur investigators who find themselves (often inadvertently) pulling on a small thread which unravels a vast conspiracy that ultimately goes "all the way to the top".

tag.name: law and order
tag.description: Where there is "wealth", there are criminals. It is up to the civil law enforcement, i.e. detectives, Police or Special Squads, to keep the lawless activities in the real world or in cyberspace under control. Note: Do not confuse this with Military presence.

tag.name: police
tag.description: The police (civil servants) are the good guys in the battle against crime. Though they try hard, they are usually outclassed by super-criminals or criminal organizations in anime, requiring the help of special units or some lone hero.

tag.name: special squads
tag.description: The Special Squads are called in when the police is completely outclassed, e.g. fighting criminal syndicates. These special forces are trained to combat specific forms of crime, e.g. the anti-cyber-crime division. There are several such squads: Whereas Section 9 of Ghost in the Shell is an official government organisation, there are also "benevolent" vigilante groups like the Knight Sabers (Bubblegum Crisis). Criminal syndicates also have their special forces e.g. "death squads".

tag.name: teamwork
tag.description: A cooperative effort by the members of a group or team to achieve a common goal.

tag.name: boy meets girl
tag.description: A classical type of plot in story writing, where the story begins with a boy meeting a girl leading to romantic development between the two. More often than not the boy loses the girl later on and has to find her again.

tag.name: randomness
tag.description: The anime does not follow a predictable storyline. New, strange, obscure, or otherwise unexpected story elements are introduced at a whim.

tag.name: Kaguya-hime
tag.description: The Tale of the Bamboo Cutter (Taketori Monogatari, 竹取物語), also known as Princess Kaguya (かぐや姫 Kaguya-hime, 赫映姫 or 輝夜姫), is a 10th-century Japanese folktale. It primarily details the life of a mysterious girl called Kaguya-hime, who was discovered as a baby inside the stalk of a glowing bamboo plant by a bamboo cutter, alongside riches in gold. The thumb-sized girl grew into a beautiful woman, and this was known all over the lands. Eventually 5 princes made their way to her to ask her foster father for her hand. Each of them got tasked with something seemingly impossible to fullfil to marry her. After all of them failed, the emporer came to see her, and fell for her beauty. His proposal was denied as well, telling him that she wasn`t of this country and thus couldn`t marry him. In the summer Kaguya-hime started to cry upon seeing the full moon. Her foster parents inquired on the matter and after a while she gave in, telling them that she was actually coming from the moon, and that she needs to return there. When the day came to return, the emperor sent many guards to her home to protect her from the moon people. They came and took her with them anyway, leaving the parents in sadness and tears. The heartbroken emperor wanted to send her a message, and went on to ask where he could find the closest place to heaven. This being the Great Mountain of Suruga Provice. The tale goes on saying that the name of the mountain, which we know today as Mount Fuji, came from the word immortality (fushi, or fuji), and the Kanji from the emperor`s army ascending its slopes, meaning literally "Mountain Abounding with Warriours" (富士山). The anime or episode either takes on the whole tale of Kaguya-hime or just parts of it.

tag.name: tales
tag.description: Tales are stories told time and again and passed down from generation to generation, and some of those show up in anime not just once or twice, but several times.

tag.name: speculative fiction
tag.description: Speculative fiction is an umbrella genre encompassing fiction with certain elements that do not exist in the real world, often in the context of supernatural, futuristic or other imaginative themes. This includes, but is not limited to, science fiction, fantasy, superhero fiction, horror, utopian and dystopian fiction, fairytale fantasy, supernatural fiction, as well as combinations thereof. Source: Wikipedia

character.name: Torii Youzou
character.description: The South Edo Magistrate, Lord of "Kai". A strong supporter of the Chief Elder Mizuno Tadakuni Tenpo Reforms.

character.name: Tamaya Seikichi
character.description: Tamaya Seikichi is a fireworks-maker who dreams of making gigantic firework no one has seen before.

character.name: Sora
character.description: A strange but beautiful girl. She asks Seikichi to make a rocket that will reach the moon.

character.name: Shunpei
character.description: Shunpei is Seikichi`s brother, and a mathematical genius. Often troubled by things that can`t be pinned down by logic and rational thinking.

character.name: Ginjiro
character.description: Ginjiro is a locksmith with a mysterious past, who can open any lock he sets his fingers on.

character.name: O-Ise
character.description: Wealthy owner of the pawn-shop Shirahama-ya. An old friend of Ginjiro from Osaka.

character.name: Tenho
character.description: Tenho is a Circus performer who specializes in sleight-of-hand.

character.name: Tenten
character.description: Tenho`s exceedingly tall brother, also a circus performer.

character.name: Akai Nishinosuke
character.description: Low-ranking policeman under the South-Edo Magistrate who hates the residents of the Furai Row-House Block.

character.name: O-Nui
character.description: The town-belle watchdog for public morality at the Furai Row-House Block. She acts like a puppy.

character.name: O-Riku
character.description: Daughter of the owner of the Kagiya Fireworks shop, and a childhood friend of Seikichi`s.

character.name: Toyama Kinshirou
character.description: The North Edo Magistrate who often ventures out to Edo under the alias of Kin-san, the Playboy.

character.name: Tetsuju
character.description: Tetsuju is a somewhat eccentric rocketeer, who lives deep inside the Chichibu mountains with bears and raccoons as friends.

episode.title: 大江戸に咲く紅い花火
Bright Red Fireworks Bloom in the Great City of Edo
Ooedo ni Saku Akai Hanabi
episode.summary: Fireworks and the rest of life’s finer things have been outlawed in Edo. The penalty for fun is harsh, but Seikichi can’t help listening to a mysterious girl’s strange proposition. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 男は待っていた
The Man Was Waiting
Otoko wa Matteita
episode.summary: Seikichi’s got a girl in his room that wants a firework-fueled ride to the moon, and there’s blood-sucking monsters running wild all over town. Coincidence? Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 縁に縛られた銀狐
A Silver Fox Bound by Fate
En ni Shibarareta Gingitsune
episode.summary: In the aftermath of more monster sightings, the magistrate recruits Ginjiro’s magic fingers for a secret mission. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: トンデモない飛んだ女
That Crazy Girl Just Flew!
Tondemonai Tonda Onna
episode.summary: Shinza’s runaway robot threatens to destroy the city until Sora flies into action. Her daring display earns her a place of honor among the row-house residents. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: ドキドキ無用
No Need to Get Excited
Dokidoki Muyou
episode.summary: Seikichi’s moon rocket gets an out-of-this-world boost from Sora. It’s time for a test flight, but they’ll need help from the row-house dwellers to achieve lift off! Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 論
The Argument
Ron
episode.summary: There’s no doubt that Tetsuju the Human Fuse knows his way around fireworks and furry little critters, but can he help Seikichi send Sora to the moon? Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 決闘大初恋
Duel to the First Love
Kekkou Dai Hatsukoi
episode.summary: Oriku is a girl from Seikichi’s past; Sora is a princess from the moon; and they both want to get their hands on his rocket! Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 恋も殺しもやるってさ
Love, Murder... He Does It All
Koi mo Koroshi mo Yaruttesa
episode.summary: Sora sheds her skin and battles the blue beast for an important piece of rocket wreckage. Ginjiro joins the hunt and learns a secret about the mysterious moon maiden. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 恋愛で勝負
Betting on Love
Ren`ai de Shoubu
episode.summary: Someone tips off Akai about fireworks at the row-house, so Seikichi and his friends must scramble to pull off a test launch. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 怪異猫変化
Madhousecatincarnations
Kaiinekohenka
episode.summary: Spies are discovered at the row-hose, and the esteemed Old Man appears to have acquired a few new cats. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 埒もねえ!
Poppycock!
Rachi mo Nee!
episode.summary: Tetsuju and Seikichi make some waves while proving that fireworks can be just as much fun on the water as they are in the sky. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: もしも悩むのが嫌だったら
If You Don`t Like Worrying...
Moshimo Nayamu no ga Yadattara
episode.summary: Shunpei wants to put an end to his worries, so he goes in search of the elusive “Naje-Naje” to discover the source of his strife. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: あんたこいつらどう思う
Whaddaya Think of These Guys?
Anta Koitsura Dou Omou
episode.summary: Ginjiro’s monster squad investigates the row-house when they begin to suspect their leader of protecting the sky beast. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 一筆啓上明日が見えた
Just to Let You Know: I Caught a Glimpse of Tomorrow
Ippitsukeijou Ashita ga Mieta
episode.summary: It’s New Year’s Eve, which means it’s time for the row house residents to spend the day in hiding - or risk having to pay their debts! Meanwhile, Oriku finds herself in hot water with the law. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 突然! 正月に大空爆
Out of Nowhere! Air Raid at New Year`s
Totsuzen! Shougatsu ni Daikuubaku
episode.summary: Seikichi’s plan to test out a new gyro-rocket takes a turn for the chaotic when Akai severs his safety-line and leaves the little man drifting towards certain death! Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: あたしがアレよ!
That Thing Is Me!
Atashi ga Are yo!
episode.summary: Sora and the blood-sucking Blue Beast bare their claws in an intergalactic cat-fight, and Seikichi’s talent for making things go “boom” is at the heart of the quarrel. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 黎明の殺し節
Killing Melody at First Light
Reimei no Koroshi Fushi
episode.summary: Sora’s secret is finally out, and the Row House residents are shocked to learn that a monster has been living in their midst. Worse yet, the shape-shifting cutie will be executed first thing in the morning! Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 相手は神君の隠し穴
Up Against the Divine Lord`s Dungeon
Aite wa Shinkun no Kakushi Ana
episode.summary: Seikichi and the rest of the row house residents hatch a plan to spring Sora from the shogun’s dungeon! When the rescue mission hits a snag, someone unexpected offers to lend a hand, but can he be trusted? Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: とち狂って候
Utter Nonsense
Tochigurutte Sourou
episode.summary: Akai’s treacherous ambush attempt is thwarted by an old, old, old friend of the Row House crew. Sora and Seikichi are free to go, but there’s still two bloodthirsty Blue Beasts on the loose! Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 難儀に微笑む女
Woman Who Smiles in the Face of Hardship
Nangi ni Hohoemu Onna
episode.summary: Akai and Ginjiro square off in a duel to the death, and Sora and Blue Girl forge an unlikely partnership to keep the third space beast from stealing the only ship that can take them home. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 脱線は三度まで
You Get Three Digressions
Dassen wa Sando made
episode.summary: Art imitates life when the Row House gang stages a play based on the adventures of Sora, Seikichi, and a rocket that goes “boom!” Theatrically speaking, the ending is happy, but how will this story wrap up in real life? Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: たった一夜の夢だった
It Was Just a One-Night Dream
Tatta Ichiya no Yume Datta
episode.summary: When Shunpei spills an enchantment potion on himself, the ladies of Edo start acting like love-struck zombies. Onui shifts shapes so she can sniff out an antidote, but she better hurry or Shunpei won’t survive the night! Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 剣舞に花火をどうぞ
Some Fireworks for the Sword Dance
Kenbu ni Hanabi o Douzo
episode.summary: Seikichi’s mission to launch a rocket to the moon is jeopardized by a mysterious gang with a penchant for swiping gunpowder. Oise is sent to investigate the matter, but what she finds might surprise her! Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: ○○をのっとれ!
Hijack the You-Know-What!
Marumaru o Nottore!
episode.summary: The Row House gang gets ready to party as the final piece of the rocket is put in place! Unfortunately, the Blue Beast rears its ugly head and prematurely ignites Seikichi’s greatest achievement! Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 匠の仕事が月に哭いて...
When a Master`s Work Cries for the Moon...
Takumi no Shigoto ga Tsuki ni Naite...
episode.summary: Ginjiro’s battle with Torii ruins the launch of yet another rocket. Later, Seikichi is approached about building something new - and this time it means war! Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: なんだかんだのリフトオフ
Somehow or Other, Liftoff
Nandakanda no Liftoff
episode.summary: Sora and Seikichi take drastic action in a desperate attempt to find peace somewhere in the universe. Meanwhile, Ginjiro and the Row House residents take a rocket ride to the moon! Source: crunchyroll
